newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: JETTIME BUYS SIX MORE AIRCRAFT FOR $48 MLN.
newsitem.headline: JETTIME BUYS SIX MORE AIRCRAFT FOR $48 MLN.

text.p: Aircraft timeshare company JetTime announced on Thursday it had bought six additional aircraft worth $48 million, bringing the number in its fleet to eight.
The six aircraft comprise three $12 million Raytheon Hawker 800 XP business jets and three $4 million Beechcraft King Air B200s.
The company, which recently launched a scheme to promote fully managed co-ownership of aircraft to the South African corporate sector, now has four of each type of airliner.

JetTime, a subsidiary of National Airways Corporation which in turn is a subsidiary of mining group Lonrho plc , will use the aircraft to launch its co-ownership concept in South Africa before operations begin in May 1997.

Clients buy a one-quarter share in an aircraft, but have access to at least four identical aircraft which are available on six hours notice, 24 hours a day for 200 flying hours a year per one-quarter share.
JetTime director Stuart Bromfield said that the eight aircraft would collectively save their 32 co-owners 77 million rand a year.
